content.question:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Solid tumors are clusters of cancer cells and often contain blood vessels. When molecule <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> binds to the wild-type <math alttext="B rec" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein in the plasma membrane of certain solid tumor cancer cells (Figure 1), the cancer cells express the membrane protein <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and sometimes stimulate increased growth of blood vessels into the tumors.

Cells with a particular mutation in the <math alttext="B rec" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene (<math alttext="B rec M U T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec-MUT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells) have much increased expression levels of <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and stimulate greater growth of blood vessels than do cancer cells with the wild-type <math alttext="B rec" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="B rec W T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec-WT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells); the cells with the mutant <math alttext="B rec" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can trigger intracellular signaling in the absence of <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Researchers proposed that the signaling pathway modeled in Figure 1 is triggered by activation of the wild-type <math alttext="B rec" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and is associated with phosphorylation and activation of kinase <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, expression of <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the ability of the cancer cells to stimulate blood vessel growth.

Figure 1. A simplified model of the normal signaling pathway hypothesized to play a role in certain cancer cells expressing <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and stimulating blood vessel growth into solid tumors

(a) Based on the signaling model shown in Figure 1, describe the role of molecule <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Solid tumors are clusters of cancer cells and often contain blood vessels. When molecule <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> binds to the wild-type <math alttext="B rec" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein in the plasma membrane of certain solid tumor cancer cells (Figure 1), the cancer cells express the membrane protein <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and sometimes stimulate increased growth of blood vessels into the tumors.

Cells with a particular mutation in the <math alttext="B rec" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene (<math alttext="B rec M U T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec-MUT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells) have much increased expression levels of <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and stimulate greater growth of blood vessels than do cancer cells with the wild-type <math alttext="B rec" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="B rec W T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec-WT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells); the cells with the mutant <math alttext="B rec" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can trigger intracellular signaling in the absence of <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Researchers proposed that the signaling pathway modeled in Figure 1 is triggered by activation of the wild-type <math alttext="B rec" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and is associated with phosphorylation and activation of kinase <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, expression of <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the ability of the cancer cells to stimulate blood vessel growth.

Figure 1. A simplified model of the normal signaling pathway hypothesized to play a role in certain cancer cells expressing <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and stimulating blood vessel growth into solid tumors

(a) Based on the signaling model shown in Figure 1, describe the role of molecule <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Explain how the addition of a phosphate group to certain amino acids of <math alttext="B rec" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> likely affects the tertiary structure and function of <math alttext="B rec" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explain how the addition of a small <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> could prevent the activation of kinase <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Based on the proposed signaling pathway, predict the relative amount of phosphorylated to unphosphorylated kinase <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the <math alttext="B rec W T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec-WT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells when the cells are grown in nutrient broth lacking <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your prediction.

(d) Cells are treated with a compound that prevents the inactivation of kinase <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Researchers claim that <math alttext="B rec W T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec-WT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells treated with this compound will stimulate blood vessel-forming cell division to the same degree as <math alttext="B rec M U T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Brec-MUT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells do in the absence of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on the information provided, provide reasoning to support their claim.

skill.text: 1.C: Explain biological concepts and processes in applied contexts.
